section.title: Combinations of Functions
section.p: There are many ways and reasons to combine two or more functions together. In the first exercise, you will combine two functions in the context of performing a familiar activity: paying bills

statement.p: Suppose you are only responsible to pay the heating and water bills each month. These bills change each month, depending on how warm you keep your house and on how much water you use.

section.p: If you need to add two functions together, such as f(x)+g(x), this represents a combination of functionscombination of functionsfunctioncombinations.
This combination is actually a new function of x, whose output is just the sum of the outputs of the functions f and g.
Of course, there are other ways to combine the outputs of two or more functions. In the next exercise, you will practice evaluating other function combinations.

section.p: Again, combining functions just means doing arithmetic on the outputs of functions. In context, we should be able to describe the meaning of different function combinations.

statement.p: For your business, you buy a certain type of item from the manufacturer, and then you sell it to your customers at a mark-up. That is, you sell it for more than you bought it.
You are concerned with the following functions regarding this item.

li.p: In month t, the function c(t) represents your cost to buy one of the items.
In month t, the function p(t) represents the price you sell the item for.
In month t, the function q(t) represents the total quantity of the items you sell that month.

statement.p: Which function combination represents the total amount your customers paid you for all the items you sell?
Answer:

hint.p: Suppose you paid c(t) = 8 dollars for each item, and you sell them for p(t) = 10 dollars per item. If you sell q(t) = 50 items, what would you really multiply together to find how much your customers paid for all of the items?

solution.p: Your customers paid p(t)q(t) for all of the items.

The function p(t) represents the price you sell the item for.

solution.p: Your profit from one item is: p(t) - c(t)

section.p: By now, you know that all combinations of functions are really just doing arithmetic on the the outputs of the functions. From a graphical standpoint, this just involves combining the y values of points on the graphs of f and g.
The next problem will have you explore the graph of a particular function combination: f(x) - g(x)
Remember that this is all about combining the outputs of the f and g functions.

statement.p: In this problem, we are considering the function h defined by: h(x) = f(x) - g(x)
The graphs of functions f(x) and g(x) are shown below.

The function h(x) is called the difference of f and g.

li.p: For which of these values is it true that h(x) = 0?
Choose an x value from the list so that h(x) has a positive output.
Choose an x value from the list so that h(x) has a negative output.

hint.p: If h(x) = 0, this means that f(x) - g(x) = 0. What would have to be true about f(x) and g(x) at that point?
Similarly, if h(x) was positive, then f(x) - g(x) > 0. Which output would have to be larger at that point, f(x) or g(x)?

li.p: h(x) = 0 when x = 4.4, because that is where f(x) = g(x).
For h(x) to have a positive output, it must be true that f(x) > g(x). Among the options given, this is only true for x = 0 and x = 2.1.
h(x) will have negative outputs when f(x) < g(x). Among the options given, this happens when x = -3 or x = 7.
